I use postmkvirtualenv to install iPython. I use postactivate to cd to a workspace dir, set any environment variables for the workspace. For Django projects I'll set the DJANGO_SETTINGS_MODULE and some shortcut aliases for common Django commands. I'll often set BYOBU_WINDOW (screen) there as well so that when I start byobu I'll have a few windows open relevant to that project (DB consoles, iPython session, etc)
@doughellmann grabs a copy every time (normal pip install), I use a PIP_DOWNLOAD_CACHE in /tmp/ though, so as long as I haven't rebooted it should stay fresh

I use postactivate for one of my projects to setup a ton of environment variables. For example, the stuff you need for Amazon EC2 and S3.
I use the postactivate hook to cd to the project directory from virtualenvwrapper.project. If it's a Django project, I also source the django_bash_completion script.
@brainsik Great idea! I assume you have a postactivate inside the environment, instead of using the global value?
@markhellewell I'll have to check out tmux, thanks for the tip.
@gthank Check out the setvirtualenvproject function. It configures virtualenvwrapper.project to cd to your project dir automatically.

@doughellmann I *knew* I hadn't needed to do that manually at one point. This is what happens when you work on multiple computers, and only in your "spare" time: you learn stuff and then forget it. Thanks, Doug.
@doughellmann Actually, I just changed it so i can keep my per virtualenv postactivate scripts in the WORKON_HOME directory. Much safer: https://gist.github.com/1009402

@doughellmann That's right. Though, that runs the risk of being lost if I ever want to build a fresh virtualenv and nuke the old one. Better would be keeping it in the global script and use a switch based on the venv name.
@brainsik You might want to look for VIRTUALENVWRAPPER_HOOK_DIR instead of WORKON_HOME. The former is the new, user-settable, override location for hook scripts.

In postactivate I cd to my workspace dir (which is always outside the .VE dir tree) and set envvars as necessary. I also added resetvirtualenv command to the wrapper script. It calls the postactivate command thus acting as a "take me home" command of sorts.
